text: Posttranscriptional regulation of macrophage <extra_id_0> tissue factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression by antioxidants .

text: <extra_id_0> Tissue factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) expression by cells of monocyte / macrophage lineage represents an important mechanism underlying the initiation of fibrin deposition at sites of extravascular inflammation .

Recent evidence suggests a role for oxidant stress in the signalling pathway of various cell types by virtue of its ability to induce DNA binding of various transcription factors , including nuclear factor kappa B and AP-1 .

The effect of antioxidant treatment on lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) - induced <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression was examined in murine peritoneal macrophages and human monocytes .

text: Both pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate , an oxidant scavenger , and N - acetyl-cysteine , a precursor of the endogenous antioxidant glutathione , inhibited stimulation of macrophage procoagulant activity by LPS .

Northern blot analysis showed that neither of these agents reduced LPS - stimulated <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA accumulation , thereby suggesting a posttranscriptional mechanism for the effect .

text: Immunofluorescence studies of human monocytes using polyclonal anti - <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibody showed that N - acetyl-cysteine treatment prevented the characteristic plasmalemmal localization of <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antigen that occurs in response to LPS .

text: Western blot analysis showed that N - acetyl-cysteine reduced the accumulation of the 47-kD mature glycoprotein in LPS - treated cells , a finding consistent with the results of the immunofluorescence studies .
Furthermore , these conditions did not result in an accumulation of the less mature forms of <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: When considered together , these data suggest that antioxidants exert their effects by impairing translation and / or by causing degradation of newly translated protein .
The effect of antioxidants on tumor necrosis factor appeared to be species specific , with no effect on LPS - induced tumor necrosis factor in murine cells , but with inhibition in human monocytes .

The posttranscriptional effect of antioxidants on <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression data suggests a novel mechanism whereby these agents might modulate monocyte / macrophage activation .
